evidence_items.text: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.
The tug instructor pulled the aircraft forward off the fence then stopped the tug.

roots_spec.exclusion_clause: Not explained by any other root

slot_statements.availability: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew was evident and observable during the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA flight on 12-25, specifically in the hist_pair_engine_t1_early phase.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The explanation of communication/coordination breakdown among crew remains robust against alternative explanations or evidence, maintaining its validity in the context of the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_pair_engine_t1_early phase.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew aligns with key features of the incident, including timing, crew interactions, and operational context during the hist_pair_engine_t1_early phase of the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA flight on 12-25.

slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The procedural deviation in pushback execution aligns with key features identified in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA's operational profile during the hist_pair_engine_t1_early phase, indicating a relevant and characteristic anomaly.

node.statement: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew was evident and observable during the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA flight on 12-25, specifically in the hist_pair_engine_t1_early phase.

assumptions: The described events reflect observable communication/coordination breakdown
No other overriding causes (mechanical/environment) dominate the incident
defeaters: If evidence showed clear, effective communication and coordination preventing the incident
If mechanical or environmental factors fully explained the event without crew communication issues

quotes.exact_quote: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.
The tug instructor pulled the aircraft forward off the fence then stopped the tug.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1-H5 describe crew communication and actions during pushback, showing coordination issues leading to the aircraft passing the TRP and hitting the blast barrier, supporting the claim of communication/coordination breakdown.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in whether procedural deviation or communication breakdown was primary cause

node.statement: The procedural deviation in pushback execution is observed and documented in the Boeing 737-8AS with registration 9H-QAA during the hist_pair_engine_t1_early phase on 12-25.

assumptions: Ground markings (TRP) were adequate and visible, so the aircraft passing beyond them indicates procedural deviation.
No mechanical control failure or communication breakdown caused the event.
defeaters: If evidence showed that the ground markings were inadequate or not visible, supporting environmental deficiency instead.
If communication failures or mechanical faults were documented causing the event.

quotes.exact_quote: The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.
After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H4 directly documents the aircraft moving beyond the designated tug release point and hitting a barrier, indicating procedural deviation. H2 and H3 show the procedural context of pushback control transfer and correction, supporting the claim. The discriminator about marker adequacy (disc:R1_PUSHBACK_PROCEDURAL_DEVIATION|R3_ENVIRONMENT_OR_MARKING_DEFICIENCY) favors procedural deviation over environmental deficiency.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No explicit evidence about marker adequacy or environmental conditions; assumption that markings were adequate.

node.statement: The procedural deviation in pushback execution aligns with key features identified in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA's operational profile during the hist_pair_engine_t1_early phase, indicating a relevant and characteristic anomaly.

assumptions: The absence of mechanical fault evidence implies the deviation is procedural.
defeaters: If evidence showed equipment fault traces or bench checks indicating control malfunction, this would favor mechanical control failure.
